awd_abstract_narration:
This project studies problems at the interface of enumerative and algebraic combinatorics.  Combinatorial questions arise in many areas of mathematics, and combinatorics has applications that include optimization, computer science, and statistical physics.  The enumerative problems under study in this project are related to parking functions (which originally arose in the study of hash functions in computer science) and the cyclic sieving phenomenon (a concept in enumerative combinatorics that interprets certain polynomial evaluations as counts of fixed points).  The research aims to both prove results in enumerative combinatorics and understand these results in terms of deeper algebraic structures.  This interaction between combinatorics and algebra promises to yield new results in both fields.  The enumerative side of the research is well-suited to broader impacts in the form of graduate and undergraduate research projects.

This project studies problems in algebraic combinatorics.  The first of these is the cyclic sieving phenomenon as it applies to the action of a K-theoretic analog of the promotion operator on a K-generalization of rectangular standard Young tableaux.  The idea is to prove new instances of the (enumerative) cyclic sieving phenomenon related to this action using representation theory.  The second problem concerns a generalization of parking functions attached to the symmetric group to a wider class of "parking spaces" attached to a reflection group W.  We study a family of conjectures regarding these objects which would yield uniform proofs of various facts in Coxeter-Catalan theory which are at present only understood in a case-by-case fashion.  The third project studies rational Catalan combinatorics, which is a generalization of classical Catalan combinatorics motivated by the study of rational Cherednik algebras.  We propose to both extend various results from the rich enumerative domain of the classical setting to the rational case and study a genuinely new feature of the rational case that we call "rational duality."

por.por_cntn:
This project performed research in algebraic combinatorics tied to the representation theory of reflection groups. The study of reflection groups goes back to the ancient Greeks in their study of the symmetric of platonic solids and representation theory (which studies these groups in terms of their actions on various spaces) goes back to the late 1800s. The inherent symmetry and beauty have helped these topics remain active areas of research today.

 

This project has resulted in results in two main fields: W-Catalan theory and generalized coinvariant theory. In joint work with Drew Armstrong and Vic Reiner, the PI introduced a "parking conjecture" which unifies, clarifies, and extends various algebraic phenomena attached to reflection groups W which were only understood in a somewhat unsatisfactory "case-by-case" fashion. Further papers were published which give evidence for this conjecture as well as extend its scope.

 

The classical *coinvariant algebra* is a graded representation of the symmetric group S_n which has been intensely studied since the mid-1900s due to its deep ties to combinatorics, algebra, and geometry. In joint work with Jim Haglund and Mark Shimozono, the PI introduced a generalization of this algebra in the context of the *Delta Conjecture* (a certain identity of polynomials), thus giving an algebraic model for the Delta Conjecture. In joint work with Brendan Pawlowski, the PI further gave a geometric model for this ring as the cohomology of a certain moduli space of "spanning line configurations". The combinatorics of both of these objects is governed by a family of *Fubini words* (preference orders of a list of n objects, where ties are allowed). This project brought algebra and geometry to an area (the Delta Conjecture) which had before only been understood on a combinatorial level.

 

The nature of research in algebraic combinatorics is such that the "combinatorial side" often provides a rich entry-point into research mathematics for junior mathematicians. During the duration of this award, the PI published 18 papers in peer-reviewed journals, several of which were coauthored by grad students or undergrads. The PI graduated 4 PhD students, one of whom is currently a tenure-track assistant professor at Beijing Jiaotong University and another of whom is working at Google. The PI also advised multiple undergraduate research projects and mentored three postdocs.
